criticalSuccess: You don't try to match strength against strength - that would be futile. Instead, you target their balance. You dart in low, positioning yourself at their center of mass. Your push isn't just forward force - it's angled precisely to exploit their high center of gravity. With expert technique, you drive upward and forward. Their size becomes their enemy. They can't help but stumble backward, their mass making the momentum impossible to stop!

Like a master judoka throwing a giant, you use physics instead of strength. You position yourself perfectly, finding the angle where even small force creates large effect. Your shove targets their balance point with surgical precision. Despite their size advantage, they stumble backward, unable to resist your perfectly applied leverage!

You read their stance and exploit the weakness inherent in their size. Your hands find the perfect position, your legs drive at the right angle. It's not about raw power - it's about leverage and timing. You push at exactly the moment they shift their weight, and their own mass betrays them. They reel backward, completely unable to stop the momentum!

criticalSuccess: This is the art of using size against itself. You study the larger foe with calculating precision, seeing not intimidating bulk but exploitable physics. They're tall - high center of gravity. They're massive - lots of momentum once moving. You position yourself with absolute precision, hands finding the exact placement that maximizes leverage. Then you explode upward and forward, pushing not just with arms but with legs, core, your entire body working in biomechanical harmony. The force is perfectly angled, timed to the microsecond of their weight shift. For one suspended moment, the giant teeters. Then physics takes over with merciless authority. Their own mass becomes the weapon. They stumble backward, feet scrambling desperately, arms windmilling for balance they can't find. They reel back several feet before regaining control. You've moved a giant through pure technique!

Like a legendary martial artist demonstrating the triumph of skill over size, you execute the perfect shove. You don't try to overpower them - that's impossible. Instead, you use leverage as your ally. You dart in close, under their reach, and position yourself at their center of mass. Your hands find purchase at exactly the right points. Then you drive forward with explosive precision, every ounce of force applied at the perfect angle to exploit their high center of gravity. The combination is inescapable. Their size, which should be an advantage, instead magnifies the effect. They lurch backward, unable to stop the momentum your technique has created. By the time they regain their balance, you've created significant distance. Proof positive that in combat, physics beats mass!
success: You employ solid technique to push the larger opponent. Moving with careful precision and proper body mechanics, you manage to generate enough leverage to move them. It's not easy - their mass resists every inch - but your skill prevails. They stumble backward, forced to yield ground to your superior technique.

Your shove uses proper positioning and leverage to overcome the size disadvantage. You target their balance point at the right moment, applying force where it matters most. The larger foe stumbles back despite their mass, moved by technique rather than brute strength.

Your technical approach is flawless - positioning, angle, timing all correct. But reality proves unkind. The larger foe's sheer bulk creates challenges your skill simply can't overcome. criticalFailure: You commit to the shove with complete confidence in your technique. You've studied leverage, practiced positioning, and you're certain you can move this larger foe. You're catastrophically wrong. You set yourself, find what you think is the perfect angle, and push with explosive force. And achieve... nothing. The larger foe doesn't just resist - they might as well be a stone pillar for all the effect your shove has. Worse, pushing against their immovable bulk throws you off balance. The jarring stop of your momentum sends you stumbling backward, arms flailing. What should have been them moving is instead you looking foolish and exposed. Size has defeated skill decisively!

Your attempt to shove the giant using leverage and technique becomes a masterclass in failure. You position yourself with what you believe is perfect precision, ready to exploit their balance. But when you execute the shove, reality intervenes brutally. Their mass is simply too overwhelming. Your push doesn't just fail - it rebounds. The force of hitting their immovable bulk throws you backward. You stumble, overextended and off-balance, while they stand there completely unaffected, perhaps not even aware you tried to move them. Your expertise has been utterly overwhelmed by simple physics!
